summary.long: Philemon is a book of the New Testament.

verses.text:
This letter is from Paul, a prisoner for preaching the Good News about Christ Jesus, and from our brother Timothy.
I am writing to Philemon, our beloved co-worker,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and to our sister Apphia, and to our fellow soldier Archippus, and to the church that meets in your house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you grace and peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I always thank my God when I pray for you, Philemon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because I keep hearing about your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love for all of God’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I am praying that you will put into action the generosity that comes from your faith as you understand and experience all the good things we have in Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your love has given me much joy and comfort, my brother, for your kindness has often refreshed the hearts of God’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why I am boldly asking a favor of you. I could demand it in the name of Christ because it is the right thing for you to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But because of our love, I prefer simply to ask you. Consider this as a request from me—Paul, an old man and now also a prisoner for the sake of Christ Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I appeal to you to show kindness to my child, Onesimus. I became his father in the faith while here in prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Onesimus hasn’t been of much use to you in the past, but now he is very useful to both of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am sending him back to you, and with him comes my own heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I wanted to keep him here with me while I am in these chains for preaching the Good News, and he would have helped me on your behalf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I didn’t want to do anything without your consent. I wanted you to help because you were willing, not because you were forced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It seems you lost Onesimus for a little while so that you could have him back forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is no longer like a slave to you. He is more than a slave, for he is a beloved brother, especially to me. Now he will mean much more to you, both as a man and as a brother in the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So if you consider me your partner, welcome him as you would welcome me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he has wronged you in any way or owes you anything, charge it to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, PAUL, WRITE THIS WITH MY OWN HAND: I WILL REPAY IT. AND I WON’T MENTION THAT YOU OWE ME YOUR VERY SOUL!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, my brother, please do me this favor for the Lord’s sake. Give me this encouragement in Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am confident as I write this letter that you will do what I ask and even more!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One more thing—please prepare a guest room for me, for I am hoping that God will answer your prayers and let me return to you soon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in Christ Jesus, sends you his greetings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my co-workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator
